/* Opening oysters */ {Citation needed|reason=If this uncited claim is true, then why can refrigerated, jarred oysters that are already removed from the shell and are very clearly dead be found in countless grocery stores?|date=December 2018}}

/* Selection, preparation and storage */ Need citations for multiple claims made in the last paragraph of the section "Selection, preparation and storage."  The entire paragraph contains no citations, but makes some rather specific claims that should be sourced. Examples:  "Oysters from the gulf coast of the United States, for example, contain high bacterial loads of human pathogens" and "''Vibrio vulnificus'' is the most deadly seafood-borne seafood-borne pathogen."

/* Selection, preparation and storage */ removed unsourced statement. This unsourced statement saying "oysters must be eaten alive or cooked alive" is obviously untrue because in countless grocery stores there can be found uncooked oysters in refrigerated jars that have already been removed from the shell and are very clearly dead and have been dead for some time
/* Nutrition */ need citation for "Dietary supplements may contain calcium carbonate from oyster shells, though no evidence shows this offers any benefits beyond what calcium may offer."
